nodes.bodyText: Teku uses Guava's Preconditions.checkNotNull and can you please include an error message.
updated as advised, however, instead of using guava, I have introduced custom helper class which raises our custom exception (but using exact same method signatures).

How did we wind up using a generic type all the way through down to here and then suddenly split into separate code paths with an instanceof?
Seems like instead of static methods here we should have just had an abstract instance method on KdfParam. Or make DecryptionKeyGenerator an interface with a generic param type and two implementations - one for SCryptParam and one for Pbkdf2Param.  Basically, we should be taking advantage of the compiler's type safety.
thats what I originally had, abstract method getDecryptionKey in KdfParam but then I refactored it out causing all these instanceof checks.
The instanceof checks are definitely bad.  So I'd go back to what you had. :)
this has been refactored to be included in KdfParam.generateDecryptionKey -> SCryptParam and PBKDF2Param classes.
Why do we support ChecksumFunction.SHA512 when it's never used in production code?
hmm...I bring it in as after thought as well, I'll get it removed.

The EIP-2335 spec leave it as open (i.e. use sha256 or any other digest function for checksum), however, I've enforced checks that we are currently only supporting sha256 as defined in spec's test vectors.
nit: checkNotNull
implemented as advised.
We should be consistent in calling this dklen or derivedKeyLength not mix the two.
dklen comes from the spec. I've updated the class to use simplified name as well as advised.

We probably shouldn't be throwing a generic Exception through this class.  Likely we need a custom exception so that the Jackson specific exceptions remain encapsulated (ie users of this class shouldn't care if we're using Jackson or gson or some other json parsing library).
👍 Going to introduce custom exception.
Introduced custom exception to cover various reportable error conditions.
nit: Preconditions.checkNotNull through this class.
updated

I'm not sure that an IllegalArgumentException is the right thing to do when the format is unsupported. It probably should be the same exception as we wind up throwing for invalid content (with clear message) so it's clear the user input was invalid vs a programmer error passing in values that should never have been passed to this function.
Basically the CLI is going to need to identify these failures as something it should report back to the user in a nice way and it can't do that if it gets very generic exception types.
Applies to the other version checks in this file too.
I suspect this is the magic 4 from below that should be a constant somewhere.
Updated to use checks and raise custom exception. Also taken care of version constant.
I'd split this into its own package private class.
done.
Are these serialisers the same as the ones needed by the REST API?  Should they be reused?
These json serializer and deserializer are specific to KeyLoader implementation.
This builder doesn't really seem warranted.  I'd just call the 3-arg constructor directly.
All the builders are gone.
This builder doesn't seem worth it either.
This builder is definitely not worth it.

nodes.bodyText: We shouldn't be doing instanceof here.  KdfParam should just have a getCryptoFunction method.
implemented method to return correct function type.
Once you get rid of the instanceof this builder doesn't seem worth it.
Just set "" as the initial value for path rather than checking for null here.
What's the magic 4 for? Probably should be a constant.
Weird to have a default value and be required. Is this just Jackson's API being weird or have we got something wrong here?
oh I missed that, defaultValue needs to go away.
Can we use a method name that actually says something about what we're testing.  I think the intent is to check key values are 32 bytes long regardless of the function used.
the tests has been refactored as suggested.

I'm not convinced the two different options really warrant using parameterised tests here.  I'd just have one test for each of the two KdfParam types - makes it much simpler to understand and almost the same amount of code.

It would be way simpler to read if we just extract a private method for the assertions and had two separate test methods for each test keystone path.  Avoids all the complexity of wrapping and unwrapping through the parameterised test machinery.
Would be much better without using parameterised tests.
This probably does make sense being parameterised as we're getting multiple tests out of the same set of parameters.
This seems like an incredibly weak assertion.  I would have expected we'd have some known inputs and expected outputs.
agreed. these are refactored.
Random in tests is a bad idea.  We should at least use an explicit seed to ensure the test is repeatable.
This also seems like too weak an assertion, suggesting we're not really testing the function.

We should be using assertj for all these assertions.  At which point you can use:
Assertions.assertThatThrownBy(() -> ...).isInstanceOf(IllegalArgumentException.class).hasMessage("...")
All the assertEquals should be assertThat(...).isEqualTo(...) as well.
Introduced assert4j.
Why is this non-static but the encrypt is static? I would expect them both be consistent in how they are used.
Changed the signature. All public methods are static and take KeyStoreData as an argument instead of using instance member.
nit: derived key length would be friendlier in an error message
They are slightly modified now.

Is there any benefit in a seperate validatePassword function instead of just calling this in decrypt before decrypting the key? Otherwise the API usage would have to be valdiatePassword followed by a decrypt(password).

The spec mentioned three methods. encrypt, validate_password, decrypt. I think validate_password are useful in scenarios where password validation is required without proceeding with actual decryption.

This could create a dk_slice greater than 16 bytes. My reading of the spec this should be exactly 16 bytes
DK_slice = decryption_key[16:32]
Updated to enforce specifying dklen >= 32
Although it does the same thing under the hood this would be clearer using Bytes.concatenate(dkSliceSecondHalf, cipherMessage)
yep, done.
What will happen if non-aes cipher is used? looks like we try unconditionally encrypt/decrypt using AES
spec is kinda open about it, but doesn't mention other alternatives. For now we have enforced aes-128-ctr.
The call to update is unnecessary you can just call doFinal with the entire message
done
Is there a more specific exception that can be used?
yes, introduced new exception and validation.
Looks like this only ever used in the tests and so should be moved out of prod code

This class really shouldn't exist.  A precondition check is there to provide early warning that a developer has stuffed up (ie it should never fail).  If we need to throw a custom exception, then this is really a part of the business logic, not a precondition.  We shouldn't hide that and make it look like a precondition check.
Particularly checkNotNull should be a precondition check and just use Preconditions from guava - something is very wrong if you're passing null where you shouldn't.  The checkArgument cases probably need to be reviewed on a case by case basis depending on whether they're checking user input (which makes it business logic) or fixed input (precondition check).
I hear you. Will remove this class and use guava instead.
Can you add a test for saving to file
added
Not liking the application logic sitting in the model, rather it was part of the keystore logic outside of the model. Is this the only way to avoid instanceof checks in the KeyStore though?
yes ... this saves us from using lots of instanceof operations
Do we need to specify the jar properties at all? Looks like this isn't need from what other modules are doing.
removed
Is there any reason you can't use the Bytes.equals method instead of Object.equals?
They are essentially same, Objects.equals is slightly better approach as both parameters are checked instead of method chain like checksum.equals(keystoredata...).
We shouldn't specify any of this.  The jar config is handled by the top level gradle build file and setup automatically for every sub module.
gone
Why are we re-throwing the same exception type?  Seems like we should just not catch it and let the original bubble up.
The initial idea was to prefix "Error in parsing" but you are right, we should bubble up original exception.

Probably need a better error message here - This isn't an error in parsing the keystore - this was a failure to read the keystore.  If one of the reasons is a FileNotFoundException (which extends IOException) we may want to handle that specifically to provide a clear message that the file path was wrong.
the message has been changed as well as filenotfoundexception is handled in seperate block as well.
